description: From Middle English beeste, beste, from Old French beste (French bête), from Latin bēstia (“animal, beast”); many cognates – see bēstia.

adjectives.description: beast (comparative more beast, superlative most beast)

entries.meaning: (slang, chiefly Midwestern and northeastern US) great; excellent; powerful
examples: There is another type from Siemens which is the HYB 39S64XXX(AT/ATL) -8B version (notice the "B" and the end) which is totally beast altogether.

definitionGroups.group: Any animal other than a human; usually only applied to land vertebrates, especially large or dangerous four-footed ones.

entries.meaning: (chiefly in Commonwealth English, more specifically) A domestic animal, especially a bovine farm animal.
examples: Boxer was an enormous beast, nearly eighteen hands high, and as strong as any two ordinary horses put together.

entries.meaning: A monstrously unusual and dangerous animal.
A person who behaves in a violent, antisocial or uncivilized manner.
(slang) Anything regarded as larger or more powerful than one of its normal size or strength.
examples: That is a beast of a stadium.
The subwoofer that comes with this set of speakers is a beast.

entries.meaning: (slang) Someone who is particularly impressive, especially athletically or physically.

examples: Shouts had been heard: 'We're coming to kill you, beasts.' In desperation, Rule 43s had tried to barricade their doors […]

entries.meaning: A thing or matter, especially a difficult or unruly one.

verbs.description: beast (third-person singular simple present beasts, present participle beasting, simple past and past participle beasted)

entries.meaning: (Britain, military) to impose arduous exercises, either as training or as punishment.
(Scotland, slang) to engage in sexual intercourse, particularly in an illicit context
examples: That teacher is under investigation for beasting wee 'uns.
